comments:
This introduction to the sociology of the family explores historical, economic, and cultural changes that have shaped the past and present form of the American kinship system. It compares demographic and social trends and consequences of the family patterns across societies, providing perspective on differences and similarities between the U.S. family system and other nations. Students have an opportunity to engage in research on topics of special interest.

Overall, students thought that the course was “interesting,” praising the readings as enjoyable and relevant. Some, however, felt that the material was repetitive and that the class “spent way too much time” on certain topics relative to others.

Many students took issue with Professor Harknett’s use of pop quizzes throughout the semester—especially since, as one student claimed, it was “unclear… how [the quizzes] would impact the grades.” Prof. Harknett was also criticized for assigning a group paper, the collaborative aspect of which students found to be “unhelpful” and “just annoying.”


Although some students claimed that the course was “not too difficult” and required only “a moderate amount of work,” a few felt that the nature of the quizzes and group paper forced the students to “put in a lot of time.”
